chapter.title: Managing resources
chapter.para: WASP is designed to be flexible in that data processing flows can incorporate steps from other flows, providing sequencing facilities to tune processing and analysis to their liking and actual environment. The standard processing flows are distributed as a guideline; however they may be modified as necessary to meet individual needs.

figure.title: Overview of hierarchy of flows to complete a MPS analysis

section.para: The diagram is intended to give an overview of the complexity of tracking all of the steps from submission of a job through to sequencing and analysis of the samples. This complexity is lessened for the developer by maintaining a modular system of flows, where a master job processing flow can be configured to run using flows specific for machines, assays, and user selected analysis requirements.

WASP flows are abstracted away from eachother where ever it is possible to increase modularity. For example, sequencing flows are abstracted away from analysis flows, so that generic analysis steps can be created to work on a common file type (for example FASTQ sequencing output). Since most reference based aligners deal with the FASTQ format, new aligner classes can easily be developed and added to existing pipelines, but does not preclude a particular implementation from going back and getting data at another level (e.g. colorspace) since files are tracked with appropriate metadata and are associated at the sample level.
